context: Starting in the late 1950s, American computer scientist <a0_0><b14_0>Paul Baran<b14_0/> developed <a0_1><a4_0><a4_1><b22_0>the concept <a0_2><a4_2><b7_0><b12_0>Distributed Adaptive Message Block Switching<b22_0/><b12_0/><b7_0/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> with <b15_0>the goal <a5_0>to <a1_0><a1_1><a5_1><b23_0>provide a <a1_2>fault-tolerant, <b8_0>efficient routing method<a1_2/> for telecommunication messages<b23_0/><b15_0/><b8_0/><a5_1/><a5_0/><a1_1/><a1_0/> as <b17_0><b18_0>part of a research program at <b13_0>the RAND Corporation<b13_0/>, <b9_0><b19_0><b20_0>funded by the <b16_0>US Department of Defense<b16_0/>.<b20_0/><b19_0/><b18_0/><b17_0/><b9_0/> <a2_0>This concept contrasted and contradicted the <a2_1>theretofore established <a2_2>principles of pre-allocation of network bandwidth<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>, largely fortified by <b10_0>the <b11_0><b26_0>development of telecommunications<b11_0/> in the Bell System<b26_0/><b10_0/>. The new concept found little resonance among network implementers until the independent work of <a6_1><a6_2><b25_0>Donald Davies<b25_0/><a6_2/><a6_1/> at the <b24_0>National Physical Laboratory<b24_0/> (United Kingdom) (NPL) in the late 1960s. <a3_0><a6_0>Davies is credited with <a3_1><a3_2>coining the modern name packet switching<a3_2/> and <b21_0>inspiring numerous packet switching networks<a3_1/> in Europe<b21_0/><a6_0/><a3_0/> in the decade following, including the incorporation of the concept in the early ARPANET in the United States.
